Award.AwardTitle: Quantum Vortex Laboratory: Generation, Manipulation, Imaging, and Dynamics of Vortices in Bose-Einstein Condensates
Award.AbstractNarration:
At high speeds, fluid flow past an object or through a tube results in turbulence, a chaotic state of flow characterized by unpredictable motion of the vortices or eddies of the flow. Turbulence is ubiquitous, commonly experienced in aircraft or watercraft, observed in rushing rivers, and may be present in blood flow. Yet despite centuries of research on turbulence, this state of fluid flow is one of the least understood phenomena in physics. Discovering its physical origins, and fully characterizing its dynamics and the transition between smooth and turbulent flows, remain significant challenges in physics. Overcoming some of these problems is essential for reaching a deeper understanding of how numerous aspects of our universe evolve. This NSF-funded project experimentally tackles aspects of fluid flows related to turbulence in a special type of fluid for which theoretical and analytical approaches have been developed. In these fluids, called Bose-Einstein condensates (BECs), microscopic droplets of gases cooled to temperatures of a few billionths of a degree above absolute zero, laser light can precisely generate, manipulate, and observe turbulence and the dynamics of the vortices that comprise turbulence. By testing theoretical predictions, this project pushes the boundaries of our understanding of these features of fluid dynamics as they appear in BECs, advancing an understanding of turbulence built up from the most fundamental framework that physicists use to describe the universe, its structure, and its dynamics.

The primary scientific aim of this project is the development of a complete understanding of quantized vortex dynamics in BECs, superfluids for which quantum mechanics governs the dynamics of fluid flow. To achieve this aim, a multi-faceted approach is pursued. First, the project builds on previous work to construct a state-of-the-art microscope designed for and dedicated to observing and measuring vortices and their dynamics directly in BECs. Second, the transition to turbulence in a two-dimensional BEC is studied by examining vortex generation as BECs are stirred by laser light. Results test key theoretical results, and help establish links between quantum and classical fluids. Third, the construction of a toolkit for on-demand creation and manipulation of vortices in a BEC is continued, building on previous successful methods that use moving laser beams to generate and manipulate vortices so that specific arrangements of vortices or types of fluid flow can be created and used on-demand in quantum fluid dynamics experiments. Finally, newly observed methods of vortex nucleation are examined in order to more fully round out an understanding of how vortices and turbulent fluid flows can be generated in BECs. By exploring the dynamics of BEC vortices, this work advances a broader understanding of quantum many-body phenomena in systems with vastly different microscopic properties, such as superfluids, superconductors, and the cores of neutron stars. The project relies on and promotes the scientific education and technical training of students, keys to maintaining national scientific strength and societal breadth and creativity.

POR.DRECONTENT:
At high enough speeds, fluid flow past an object results in turbulence, a disordered state of the flow that is characterized by unpredictable motion and interactions of vortices within the fluid.  In a typical turbulent fluid, these vortices may be injected into the flow as the fluid moves past an object or near a surface, after which they break up into ever smaller vortices.  In two-dimensional flows, this behavior may be reversed: the vortices injected into the fluid can merge and grow into much larger vortices.  Such fluid dynamics has relevance to atmospheric dynamics, dispersal of particulates in the ocean, and the longevity of Jupiter?s Great Red Spot.   While many characteristics of such two-dimensional turbulence have been well studied, challenging problems remain, and new experimental platforms are needed to quantitatively study and better understand this state of fluid flow. 

 This NSF-funded project continued earlier experimental investigations and development of techniques involving two-dimensional turbulence, vortices, and dynamics of vortices in a special type of fluid for which theoretical and analytical approaches have been developed that closely match experimental conditions and which derive from the foundations of quantum mechanics.  In these fluids called Bose-Einstein condensates (BECs), microscopic droplets of gases cooled to temperatures of a few billionths of a degree above absolute zero, laser light can precisely generate, manipulate, and observe the state of fluid flow in ways not possible with everyday fluids such as water.  Previously, NSF funded projects demonstrated new means of looking at challenging aspects of fluid dynamics in entirely new ways.  In a previous award, a significant outcome was the initial development of new microscope that allowed for the direct optical imaging of vortices in BECs, opening up new possibilities for determining the dynamics of these fluids.  Other outcomes demonstrated the viability of techniques to generate vortices and states of turbulence in a BEC, and how these states can be experimentally manipulated.  Essentially, previous work firmly showed that BECs can indeed serve as unique and important systems for exploring and developing new understandings of aspects of vortex dynamics and two-dimensional turbulence, particularly as they relate to the laws of quantum mechanics. 

The aims of this most recent NSF-funded project were to take these initial steps even further by developing additional understanding of the dynamics of quantum vortices in BECs, constructing a toolkit for on-demand creation and manipulation of vortices and thus the superfluid state of a BEC, characterizing vortex nucleation mechanisms, and developing vortex distribution and dynamics measurement techniques.  The outcomes successfully accomplished the goals.  In particular, this project:

 -       Pushed the boundaries of vortex imaging in a BEC, including discovering conditions that permit vortex imaging in experimental scenarios in which phase transition dynamics and turbulence appear.   Methods to overcome these limits in future work are better understood and implementation of these new methods has begun.

-       New on-demand and controlled vortex creation mechanisms were investigated, and the ability to create clusters of vortices is now better understood and the techniques will augment studies of 2D quantum turbulence, vortex clustering, and collisions of vortices.

-       As an unexpected but nevertheless significant outcome, a new vortex manipulation method that was proposed and tested revealed a new means of removing unwanted vortices from a BEC that can appear through various mechanisms.  This technique will have application in a wide variety of 2D superfluidity experiments that require initial states that are vortex free.

-       The decay of dark soliton trains, or lines along which fluid is absent, were found to decay to vortices, and various experimental parameters were studied.  This experiment may be a quantum mechanical and superfluid analogue of how colliding gas regions, such as perhaps may be found in the atmosphere, can generate pressure waves (or sound) that decay to regions of fluid circulation (vortices) and create turbulence.

-       Various experimental tests also showed that additional numerical work is warranted on vortex research, and preliminary results on new measurement vortex measurement techniques were proposed that will be numerically investigated further. 

 

Overall, this project pushed the boundaries of explorations of fluid dynamics as manifested in BECs, advancing an understanding of two-dimensional turbulence from the standpoint of quantum mechanics, the fundamental framework that physicists use to describe the universe, its structure, and its dynamics.  The outcomes of this project thus serve a broader impact of advancing the sciences of turbulence and fluid dynamics in entirely new ways.  By exploring the science of vortices in BECs, this work has helped advance and motivate theoretical approaches to fluid dynamics problems within the framework provided by quantum mechanics.  Finally, this award supported graduate students to develop and utilize rigorous experimental methods and integrate these methods with theoretical approaches, thereby promoting the scientific education and technical training of students, keys to maintaining national scientific strength and societal breadth and creativity.
